headline.main: The Series: What They Talk About

docs.lead_paragraph: THE joint baseball committee studying the question of compensation for teams that lose free agents has held two meetings without coming to blows. To add that the members have not come to agreement, either, would be tautology at ...

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Study Unit's Study

docs.lead_paragraph: THE American Civil Liberties Union has taken no public position on the pennant race in the National League East, although it is possible that some of the organization's 125,000 members consider Rusty Staub a cuddlier character than Dock Ellis and privately root for the Expos against the Pirates. However, the A.C.L.U. does take a firm stand on the Constitution of the United States and the 26 amendments thereto.
docs.abstract: Red Smith on American Civil Liberties Union preparing to take baseball Comr Bowie Kuhn to court for fining pitcher Bill Lee for his statement that he used marijuana; illus of Lee (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: "The frank yet graceful use of 'I' distinguishes a good writer from a bad column," Ambrose Bierce wrote. "The latter carries it with the manner of a thief trying to cloak his loot."

headline.main: As I Was Saying a While Back; Sports of The Times Time Stumbles On The Scapegoats

docs.lead_paragraph: THE two liveliest minds in baseball left the game high and dry last week, and it's going to take more than snap judgment to decide whether this left the game richer or poorer. Did the welcome departure of Charlie Finley compensate for the loss of Bill Veeck?
docs.abstract: Red Smith column on Finley career; illus (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Two Mavericks Depart

docs.lead_paragraph: MIAMI When the St. Louis Browns moved to Baltimore in 1954, they had stormed through the American League for a total of one pennant in all their existence, and no other team in the major leagues could make that statement.

headline.main: Earl Weaver Didn't Cut His Throat; Sports of The Times Jim Palmer & Co. Most Resilient Manager

docs.lead_paragraph: From now until February, sportswriters in every city in the major leagues will be favored with campaign literature as if they needed it this soon after Nov. 2 from volunteers promoting various candidates for the baseball Hall of Fame.
